content.statement: aku-051-mvt-treatment is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Mesenteric-Ischemia that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku-051-mvt-treatment helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku-051-mvt-treatment include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku-051-mvt-treatment.

agents.dosing: Bolus 80 U/kg, then 18 U/kg/hr; target aPTT 1.5-2.5x control
Enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC q12h or equivalent

initial_therapy.timing: Initiate immediately upon diagnosis—do not wait for confirmatory tests if clinical suspicion high
initial_therapy.duration_initial: Continue until clinically stable and transitioned to oral anticoagulation

transition_to_oral.timing: When patient tolerating oral intake and stable

options.overlap: Overlap with heparin for 5+ days and INR therapeutic for 24+ hours

options.advantage: No monitoring, fixed dosing, fewer interactions
considerations: Limited data specifically in MVT (extrapolated from VTE trials)
May be preferred in patients with cancer (rivaroxaban, edoxaban)
Avoid if severe liver disease or renal impairment
options.trend: Increasing use; non-inferior to warfarin in VTE

provoked_mvt.definition: Identifiable transient risk factor (surgery, infection, medications)
provoked_mvt.rationale: Risk factor removed; recurrence risk lower

unprovoked_mvt.rationale: Higher recurrence risk; weigh bleeding vs thrombosis

malignancy_associated.agent: LMWH or DOAC preferred over warfarin
malignancy_associated.duration: Duration of cancer treatment; indefinite if persistent

bowel_rest.indication: NPO initially for all acute MVT
bowel_rest.duration: Until pain improving and bowel function returning

fluid_resuscitation.rationale: Third-spacing into bowel wall and mesentery

antibiotics.regimen: Same as for arterial ischemia (pip-tazo, carbapenem)

pain_control.approach: Opioids as needed; monitor for ileus

approach.transhepatic: Access portal vein percutaneously through liver

catheter_directed_thrombolysis.monitoring: Serial imaging to assess response; watch for bleeding
catheter_directed_thrombolysis.outcomes: May improve portal vein patency; limited comparative data

tips_for_portal_hypertension.role: Not first-line; consider if chronic portal hypertension develops after MVT

indications: Signs of bowel necrosis (hemodynamic instability, acidosis, bloody stool)

procedure.resection: Remove frankly necrotic bowel; preserve maximum length
procedure.venous_thrombectomy: Generally NOT attempted (technically difficult, clot extends into small veins)

hypercoagulable_workup.timing: After acute phase; some tests affected by acute thrombosis and anticoagulation

tests_to_consider.timing: Off heparin; affected by acute thrombosis
Best tested off anticoagulation; confirm 12 weeks later

additional_workup.imaging: CT or MRI to rule out occult malignancy (especially pancreatic, hepatic)
additional_workup.hematology_referral: If inherited thrombophilia or myeloproliferative disorder suspected

clinical_pearls.pearl: MVT has a more forgiving timeline than arterial ischemia—anticoagulation is the first-line treatment, not surgery
clinical_pearls.implication: Resist the urge to rush to surgery; anticoagulation allows many patients to avoid operation

clinical_pearls.pearl: An underlying hypercoagulable state is found in 60-80% of MVT cases—workup is essential to guide anticoagulation duration
clinical_pearls.implication: Perform thrombophilia workup after acute phase; results dictate lifelong vs. time-limited therapy

clinical_pearls.pearl: DOACs are increasingly used for MVT, extrapolating from VTE data, though warfarin remains well-established
clinical_pearls.implication: Both are acceptable; choose based on patient factors and monitoring capability

clinical_pearls.pearl: Peritonitis mandates surgery—anticoagulation cannot salvage necrotic bowel
clinical_pearls.implication: Don't delay operation hoping anticoagulation will work if peritoneal signs are present

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
